messages.text:
Are UK vacations per day periodic?
I can imagine a peak on certain days like e.g. a bunch of GPs were opening up on Saturday solely for vaccinations only.
And a ton being closed entirely on Sunday

But not that it seems the peak is followed by a trough and slowly builds back up.

Are they running out of vaccines, then not sure when they will get more and so don't pre-book patients?
And then patients need a few days notice to get in?

messages.text: This is big: <https://www.ox.ac.uk/news/2021-02-02-oxford-coronavirus-vaccine-shows-sustained-protection-76-during-3-month-interval>

attachments.title: Oxford coronavirus vaccine shows sustained protection of 76% during the 3-month interval until the second dose | University of Oxford
attachments.text: Analyses reveal single standard dose efficacy from day 22 to day 90 post vaccination of 76% with protection not falling in this three-month periodAfter the second dose vaccine efficacy from two standard doses is 82.4% with the 3-month interval being used in the UK. (82.4% effective, with a 95% confidence interval of 62.7% - 91.7% at 12+ weeks)Data supports the 4-12 week prime-boost dosing interval recommended by many global regulatorsAnalyses of PCR positive swabs in UK population suggests vaccine may have substantial effect on transmission of the virus with 67% reduction in positive swabs among those vaccinated
attachments.fallback: Oxford coronavirus vaccine shows sustained protection of 76% during the 3-month interval until the second dose | University of Oxford

messages.text:
Its still pretty amazing to me that *all* vaccine trials I am aware of getting to the approval stage have shown 100% effectiveness in preventing death.
You might get sick.
There is a small chance you end up in  hospital.
You won’t die.

messages.text: <https://academictimes.com/first-vaccine-to-fully-immunize-against-malaria-builds-on-pandemic-driven-rna-tech/|https://academictimes.com/first-vaccine-to-fully-immunize-against-malaria-builds-on-pandemic-driven-rna-tech/>

attachments.title: First vaccine to fully immunize against malaria builds on pandemic-driven RNA tech
attachments.text: Consistently ranked as one of the leading causes of death around the world, malaria doesn’t have an effective vaccine yet. But researchers have invented a promising new blueprint for one — with properties akin to the novel RNA-based vaccine for COVID-19.
attachments.fallback: First vaccine to fully immunize against malaria builds on pandemic-driven RNA tech

attachments.title: The traffic impact of Covid - Marginal REVOLUTION
attachments.text: For the first time since 2007, preliminary data from the National Safety Council show that as many as 42,060 people are estimated to have died in motor vehicle crashes in 2020. That marks an 8% increase over 2019 in a year where people drove significantly less frequently because of the pandemic. The preliminary estimated rate of […]

messages.text:
A Julia Lab project got to mainstream news!

<https://gizmodo.com/researchers-are-working-on-a-virtual-phone-virus-that-m-1846478050>

attachments.title: Researchers Are Working On a Virtual Phone Virus That 'Mimics' the Spread of Covid-19
attachments.text: In an effort to assist the evolving science of contact tracing, researchers have created a virtual phone virus that is meant to “mimic” the spread of Covid-19. By “infecting” phones within a controlled environment, the researchers hope to gain a better understanding of the trajectory of viruses as they proliferate within a given population.
attachments.fallback: Gizmodo: Researchers Are Working On a Virtual Phone Virus That 'Mimics' the Spread of Covid-19

messages.text:
I’ve noticed that my view of the situation has changed a lot after I got the AZ vaccine. (Just the first shot so far, close to two weeks ago.)
Two weeks ago I mostly wanted to hide. Now I’d like to throw a party. Well, I can’t do that since it’s forbidden in Finland, and we’re going into stricter lockdown in a couple of weeks (probably). I hope we get more vaccines soon!

messages.text: <https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-astrazeneca-pei-idUKKBN2BM1G8>

attachments.title: Germany's vaccine regulator reports 31 cases of blood disorder after AstraZeneca shot
attachments.text: Germany's vaccine regulator said on Tuesday it has recorded 31 cases of a rare blood clot in the brain, nine of which resulted in deaths, after people received a COVID-19 vaccine from AstraZeneca.
attachments.fallback: U.S.: Germany's vaccine regulator reports 31 cases of blood disorder after AstraZeneca shot

messages.text:
Something I don't understand.
The US is starting to open up for vaccinating the general population (depending on state).
The UK is not too far away from that either.
But the US has  vaccinated  with at least 1 shot a bit under a third the population, where as the uk has vaccinated a bit under half.

I have 4 possible explanation:
 - US has much lower uptake by choice, because AntiVaxers (That fits a stereotype, but I don't know that it's true. Esp amoungst vulnerable groups)
 - US has much lower uptake due to challenges navigating the system (the system in the US sounds really complex, but complex enough to loose a third of all vulnerable people?)
 - US has fewer vulnerable people due to how they are classifying people. (So they don't have about 50% the  population in any kind of prioritized group. Easy way for this is if the age brackets are cutoff differently. UK's bottom vulnerable group is only 50 years old.)
• US has fewer vulnerable people due to demographic differences (younger population would be the big one)
